@SmarterEveryDay - When you place the PR drop into the epoxy a great deal of heat is quickly transmitted from the epoxy into the cooler glass mass. This serves to quick cool the epoxy that is in direct contact with the PR drop. That temperature reduction alters the hardening of the epoxy in a zone where the heat has been lost to the glass. This in turn serves to create a "glove" of quick cured epoxy around the drop itself. In order to mitigate the affect, you would need to stir the hot uncured epoxy with the PR drop you are using in order to bring them into temperature equilibrium.

This would theoretically reduced the inhibiting effect of the cooled (quickly cured) epoxy glove around the PR drop itself. It would also allow you to have a tactile feedback from the epoxy while stirring to allow you choose a more desirable viscosity for the triggered PR drop explosion. I surmise that this would allow for a more vibrant explosion of the PR drop within the more temperature/viscosity homogenized epoxy medium.

Why not try it in Jell-O, agar agar, ballistics gel, or silicone, to measure what you can in each of those?

Also, why not put a LID over the boxes, to capture or contain some of the shockwaves?

Also also, what about finding ways to MIX the epoxy resin under the vacuum (which could take some finangling), to better ensure uniformity in mixing WHILE (simultaneous to) extracting and unwanted air? That way the time-clock isn't such a series-event limit, but parallel processes (mixing + degassing)?

There's got to also be other ways, albeit considerably more complicated, of forming larger things with similar properties, like maybe on the 0 G airplanes or something, to form larger globules that don't drop in such a tell-tale size and shape. I'd like to see those other shapes tested further, too, for these properties.

And is there a way to use spectroscopy to measure the differential densities of the glass throughout, that our naked eyes can't see? I think at a Fisher Scientific thing once some brand was advertising their glassware being more uniform than a competitor, and they used a polarizer or spectrometer to show the inconsistencies of one brand's glassware versus theirs.

These would all be neat variables I would like to see measured and/or tested for.

I think that a non-newtonian fluid like corn starch mixed at a ratio that approximates the density of the glass would probably be the best medium to break the drop. This would slow down the fastest particles the fastest as they expand outwards, and the particles would not sink to the bottom quite as fast or at all if the density is right. Of course, it would not be completely frozen in the liquid, but I think it would be relatively still for the high speed time frame.

Seems to me that epoxy is just too dense, though there were some nice ones in there as well. Aerogel can be used to capture space debris, but I don't know exactly how much you'd need to stop the Prince Rupert Drop explosion. Something in between like ballistic gel might be better.

The benefit would be that you would allow the gel to finish setting before setting off the explosion, so it would be as homogeneous as it can be. Downside is you don't wind up with a semi-permanent sculpture as a keep-sake.

Give up on viscosity.  It would be really interesting to see what happens if you suspend the drop in the epoxy and allow it to fully cure.  Wait for the entire system to equalize so the drop and cured resin are the same temperature, then try the experiment.  Another thing that would be really interesting is to fully cure, then freeze the entire system and try the experiment. Hi. Love your videos. This one is great ... but there's a lot of room for improvement with regard to your epoxy processing. 1) Use an appropriate epoxy: The one you are using is meant for surface finishing in thin layers. Making big quantities in deep sections is a bad idea, as the exotherm will be so high, the cure will be uncontrollable, and a fire risk. 2) Mix, mix, mix! Mix until clear, then transfer to another container, and mix some more. 3) Removing bubbles with a vacuum only results in boiling of one of the epoxy components, changing the ratio slightly. Probably won't make much difference, but all those bubbles coming out of the epoxy are not trapped air bubbles. I would LOVE to see one of those results sawn in half, and put under a microscope!! Keep up the good work.

Ahh, it made a vacuum! The outside cooled first and solidified, and the inside continued trying to shrink but couldn't because the outside was already solid. Once the tail is shattered, the restriction is removed. The inside contracts instantly when the outside can't prevent it anymore, creating a vacuum inside the area defined by the PRD. Because you have it encased in partially solidified resin, the air is drawn down in between the fragments to fill the vacuum just like sucking it through a straw. That wouldn't happen if it wasn't in the resin because air would be able to come in from all sides. That's where your air bubble came from. The whole dynamic is probably a key part of what's happening to the PRD when it's shattered, too.
If you wanted to see the movement of the fragments, you might consider using ballistics gel next time. That would avoid the pitfall of "we took too long mixing it and it hardened up too much".

Three things today…

Are you corresponding with Aben, Chandrasekar, and Chaudhr? I became interested in Prince Rupert drops back when I started glassblowing in the 90s. Abe, et. al. did some great work with pressure and stress distribution in the PRD, including measuring the internal pressure in the gigapascal range.

Decent casting epoxy will have a table of the proper resin/hardener ratio vs. thickness to keep the exothermic reaction from running away. That's what caused the "magic smoke" and cording. You were pretty close to the point where it would all turn brown, shrink down, crack apart, or catch fire. It looks like you were using a surface coating formula: the sort of thing you use to make a cheesy restaurant table, not to pot something.

If you cut the molten glass instead of letting it trail off, then drop it into a bit deeper water or into oil, you will get a roughly spherical, tail-less blob with similar supertempered properties, but no way to explode it aside from a hardened point impact. As an interesting aside, kids marbles often exhibit some tempered behavior. A marble making machine releases uniform sized blobs of glass into a semicircular metal track and this cooled the surface much faster than the center.

23 minutes is too long, it can be really fluid one moment and can then hard within minutes.

Mixing properly at the start is important, then you have it well mixed and more fluid, more time.

If you asked me I'd let it set. Or keep it steady while feeling for resistance gently, then clip it when it "feels" right. It's an art, not a science.

Also, a spatula is good for mixing. Wooden, metal "blade". For walls and plaster and such, one of those.

Also, vacuuming the first container then slowly pouring it into the second may give you a better result with fewer bubbles. This will depend on how fast it sets and how well you can pour without getting bubbles, though you may be able to pour it in stages, previous epoxy can stick to new if you follow it up quickly enough (minutes-hours, not days, rapido rapido). When you mix epoxy, try putting just a round dow rod or round smooth metal rod in the drill.  You don't need it to paddle the epoxy to mix it.  The rotation of the rod and surface tension will mix the epoxy.  Also, don't go up and down.  Just bottom the rod on like a glass bottom and move it around.  You won't get many bubbles

You have to mix your resin SLOWLY (to prevent bubbles) and THOROUGHLY (to prevent cloudiness), that's why it's all cloudy! That's the boundary layer between unmixed components! They recommend mixing slowly in the middle of the container for a minute, then starting to mix in the edges of the resin that are stuck on the outer parts of the container. You have to mix it for at least 3 minutes, maybe 5 minutes, until it starts being clear and not cloudy. THEN you pour it into your destination container.

For anyone curious: The reason it fragments this way is because the inside is under tension, and when you break the tail, that tension is released along the spine of the drop as material is pulled outwards towards the surface. It's the momentum from the spring-back that causes the surface to explode outwards.

I've always wondered if you could make a Prince Rupert's Drop, but without the tail... IDK, somehow cool a perfect sphere of glass in the same way, to make a piece of glass that's just basically indestructible. Ideas include using glass that's just barely molten all the way through and spinning it to maintain a spherical/oval shape, then dropping it into water... or perhaps melting the glass in some kind of vessel that keeps it spherical/oval, which can then have the supports removed and water dumped in in very quick succession.

I've also wondered what happens if you heat the part where the tail joins to the head and melt it onto the drop. Would that cause it to shatter, would you end up with something like what I described earlier, or would it do something else entirely?

If you could manipulate stresses inside of a material very precisely, creating stress patterns like those seen in a Prince Rupert's Drop but without the "weak spot", I think that might be extremely useful for next-gen armour. I'm guessing that could probably be done with lasers, nanotechnology, or zero-g fabrication? Imagine lightweight (relative to comparable steel) armour made from glass or another material, using the same technique to make it virtually indestructible. The following question is - can this be done with materials other than typical glass? Might an already-super-hard ceramic like silicon carbide exhibit the same effect? If so, would it be even MORE indestructible than the glass versions?

For all I know, militaries are already doing something like this to make armour and I just guessed at some highly-classified technology... but I kinda doubt it tbh. Would definitely be interested in working on that - I think the gap between armour technology and weapons technology has been too large for too long, and I want to see an defensive paradigm other than just "don't get hit" become effective/dominant again. The lightning-quick and super-agile nature of modern conflict puts the defender at far too great of a disadvantage, and gives the aggressor far too much advantage for my liking. If conflict becomes a slow, grinding slugfest (excluding the nuclear nightmare - no one wants to see that) due to advances in defensive technologies, the advantage could be shifted over to the defender's side... and I think that's a good thing. Going on the attack should always be disincentivised as much as possible.

If it could work: Perhaps imagine a fighter jet or a battleship with ultrahard, ultra-tough ceramic armour like that... I mean, if it can resist gunfire at small sizes, why couldn't it be scaled up? Then your fighter jet might turn from a "glass cannon" into a literal glass-coated cannon that can straight-up tank just about anything coming its way, as long as it doesn't, say, get hit in the engines... also, HUGE naval ships could become militarily viable again, as the larger a ship is the smaller its surface area to volume ratio - maybe super-battleships with armour that can take incredible punishment and resist even modern weapons with relative ease, while carrying a totally unparalleled armament (gigantic missile batteries, enormous main guns for shore bombardment, maybe even next-gen weapons like giant railguns or laser-based CIWS)... also maybe personal body armour that can shatter/deflect 20mm cannon rounds all day - sure, the shock waves would probably still cause some serious issues, but I'm sure there's a way that can be mitigated.

What do I know, though? I'm prolly just dreaming/getting overexcited... I sincerely doubt any of that is actually possible - at least not with today's technology, or even tomorrow's. If it were, I'm sure people far brighter than me would already be on it, and would likely have figured out how to do it already.

If you don't whip the resin, you shouldn't need to degas it. The streaks indicate it's not well mixed. I always mixed by hand and it was fine. You stir and scrap bottom and sides constantly. Then you pour into a second cup and stir there, scraping bottom and sides, then you pour onto your surface but do not scrape the cup. The table top resin at least, is designed to push bubbles to the surface. you shouldn't need a vacuum chamber.

Even when just using epoxy in small amounts for repairs and such you should glove up. Epoxy sensitization is very common and depending on person it can develop in just few exposures. The symptoms are usually a really nasty localized dermatitis/eczema where your skin just keeps peeling off in chunks for days or weeks, but there are people who have to hospitalized even if they are down wind of shop or a factory that uses them.

I believe I saw a shattering wavefront moving from the pinch point towards the bulb, then noticed the shockwave back and forth across the tank, but then also noticed a compressive wavefront moving backwards from bulb toward the tail, and as the compressive wavefront moved backwards towards the tail, THAT'S when the shank and tail particles exploded away from the original position. Importantly, I believe there was a significant delay between the shank and tail shattering and THEN exploding away from the original position, and I believe the shank explosion waited for the returning compressive wavefront from the bulb towards the tail. I believe I perceived a progressive explosion along the length of the shank, from bulb towards the tail. Pretty fast from the pinch down towards the bulb, but then fairly faster from bulb back to pinch. I'm pretty sure that the "wing-like air bubble is a cavitation that was caused by the outward pressure from the PRD exploding and separating the partially cured resin into a layer. What you are seeing the air between the two created layers. As epoxy resins cure, they become a jelly state, as you noticed on the first batch when you tried to place the PRD inside. This jelly tends to split in straight lines, much like the way some dry desert earth does. I think it has to do with the expanding forced of the exploding PRD and the contracting forces of the curing resin. I'm no scientist, but I'm a professional custom fiberglass fabricator for nearly 15 years.

Ok, on the wing-like bubble…
When the drop is exploding, it is exerting a pressure outward (ie, the definition of explosion). It is followed by a rarefraction, the space between the shards is normally filled by atmosphere. However, the curing epoxy is too thick to completely fill the voids, leaving the spaces at a lower pressure. Eventually the epoxy also cures and cools, further reducing the pressure inside and the tail provides a pathway for air to get in.
So, experiment proposal: cut the acrylic and drop in half to see if the epoxy was able to infiltrate the glass or not. If not, then my theory is out.
If the epoxy didn’t infiltrate, test to see how quickly some sort of diffusion happens down the shattered tail.

For the wing bubble - this looks like air finding its way into an already present crack and displacing the fluid that had filled it. It seems that, during that particular attempt, the epoxy was more set than it was during the other attempts, considering it didn't splash as the shockwave hit the surface. The epoxy could have been solid enough that the explosion caused the epoxy around the expanding PRD to shear rather than flow out of the way. This would make an invisible crack, as there was still some liquid resin filling it. Then, as the resin continued to polymerize throughout the cube, it likely got sucked up into the structure, reducing the pressure inside the crack and pulling the air that was once inside the bulb of the PRD into the crack.

Destin w/ "SED". I really appreciated your work with the Prince Rupert's Drop! It's been a puzzling mystery for centuries. As a glass artist, it holds perhaps an extra measure of curiosity, as there's remained a desire to (like you) capture the explosion of the glass for a more permanent display. Just a couple of observations: Something I've learned from working with epoxy resins - if you don't want air bubbles, don't mix any air into the liquid! Perhaps a magnetic stirring set up could help reduce the amount of infused air? Your glassblower friend should be able to easily create not only colored glass PRD's, but multiple colored drops. A "cane" of glass can be done with a clear glass center, a red glass middle, and perhaps a thin blue outer layer - of course the color selection would be up to your choices. But perhaps similar multi-colored glass PRD's would permit you to establish just what part of the drop was moving where. Could the inner portions of the PRD have more or less explosive energy? Maybe just set one off on a large sheet of white paper, and see if you can analyze the colors and distance of the fragments? With your high speed video, you might even be able to "see" the dynamics of the multi-colored glass take place as it explodes? Remember as well, that law of physics - for every action, there's an equal and opposite reaction. At least in part that might explain the way the drop reduces back after the initial explosion. The resin had already sorta "set", so there was no flow of any resin back into the void, I do think that as you surmised, it was the air's pressure that forced the air into the void or cavity. Since you have the vacuum set up, perhaps try repeating the explosion without any air pressure - might allow a more liquid resin to invade the cavity. Finally, I'll offer one further idea. Rather than immersing the PRD in almost solid resin, or coating the PRD with same, how about coating the PRD with something really flexible, like liquid latex (often used for complex mold making). At least it might confine the particles a bit better, and with any luck the particles at least on the outside of the PRD could be captured for analysis (are particles all same size, or are there variations related to position on the PRD? Well your experiment will probably continue teasing my brain for some time to come, so I thank you and wish you further success!

I don’t know much about prince Rupert’s drops, but I do have some trial-and-error knowledge on the epoxy stuff. Basically since epoxy is an exothermic reaction, the reason you have different curing times in the same pour is because of how heat can escape in it. When you got a small opening to air from the explosion, there was a more direct way to release heat and then the rest of the epoxy cured and shrank around that crack, causing it to grow bigger as the epoxy cured

@15:51 - it sure looks like a temporary wound cavity to me... My hypothesis is thus:

The epoxy was largely cured, but wasn't "solid" yet. When the PRD shattered, the transfer of energy to the epoxy medium was such that it caused a then-invisible shockwave in said medium, which when cured, ultimately causing the feather split you see at the bottom of that particular casting.

With certain ballistics gel tests, you typically see these exact types of big splits in the wound channel. But, that's a gelatinous medium, where this epoxy is hardening to a solid medium. BUT, said epoxy wasn't entirely cured into said solid medium... So, the shockwave split the epoxy, but it was not visible until the epoxy fully solidified...

Just my theory. :)

Just an idea for Destin: When exploding Prince Rupert's drops, make sure you cover all of your exposed skin. Why?

Watching someone mix epoxy with a power tool is so hard to watch knowing that is probably the worst way to mix epoxy. Mix epoxy too fast and you add tiny air bubbles that give it that cloudy look. A good 5 minutes of slowly stirring by hand is typically all you need, and you wouldn't need to put it in a vacuum to get the bubbles out. Usually, you can use a heat gun or blow torch to heat up any bubbles in the epoxy and they rise to the surface like tiny hot air balloons.

joke aside: resins are meant for applications for a reason. that reason being the tuning of the exothermic polymerisation reaction. essentially what's happening with your pours, that are way too high volume for the type of resin you're using, is a runaway thermal "spiral reaction" of "resin reacting emits heat" and "heat makes reactions faster". rule of thumb: if your resin smokes, you're using the wrong kind for the application (also probably need new lungs, and pray it doesn't start spitting burning goo too)

I'm not an expert on resin but it feels like you're going about it the wrong way here. The mixatron 3000 is probably one of the worst ways to go about this since it introduces WAY too much air in the system. You're probably having a lot of problem on day 1 cause you're mixing too much resin at once and it's getting too hot, reducing the container size helped you on that. I don't think mixing after the pour is a good idea, that probably doesn't help in the homogeneity of the final resin. Deep pour resin with a longer set time would make the whole experience way easier and it'd likely give you a lot more leeway to experiment with timing so you could tune the viscosity.

You have such a promising experiment here that I'm captivated by, but the low quality of resin, reaction speed (very low resolution viscosity window), and incomplete mixing (heterogeneous reaction) significantly impacted the results. I'm only compelled to say this by how excited I am to see this work out. With a bit more control, this could be both visually and scientifically beautiful.

I've seen a lot of comments on here saying that the streaking is from the epoxy not being mixed thoroughly. I don't think this is the case. If you look closely as he's degassing the second batch, 12:57, there are not any streaks. However, at 13:00, there are streaks. These streaks are due to the inhomogeneous heat distribution in the fluid causing lines of varying refractive index. You will see this when mixing hot and cold water together, or any other fluid whose refractive index has sufficient temperature dependence to create a noticeable difference.

@SmarterEveryDay, I've seen epoxy that was poured too thick spontaneously combust. Once you see smoking, you're in the danger zone. The chemicals in the resin aren't necessarily super flammable, but they are a source of carbon that could ignite if hot enough. Please be careful.

The hotter your resin gets, the faster it'll cure and the hotter it gets. Awesome little feedback loop. If you want to slow it down there are three options: use a slower formula epoxy, use a mold with a higher surface area to volume ratio, and start with cooler resin. Keeping it in the fridge isn't a terrible idea. Building boats we'd almost always use multiple small batches and layup only 1-2 plies at a time; if you try to do a whole bucket it'd be hard by the time you get the 20 feet back to where you needed it.

We had really good results with System Three general purpose resin and #2 or #3 (medium and slow respectively) hardeners. Given the low surface area you'd be much happier using the slow stuff. Conversely you could use a polyester casting resin and just go really easy on the catalyst to control cure time.

I think your problem getting the results your after is the quality of epoxy. The stuff you're using just isn't good quality and is suffering from thermal runaway. I'd recommend getting either a casting epoxy or tabletop epoxy of good quality. Pro Marine and SuperClear are two I've used that cure with a consistent viscosity, and their longer cure times will also allow you to target a more specific window.

Another issue I see here is the mixing. Epoxy has to be mixed VERY well, which includes scraping the bottom and sides, and making sure those portions gets mixed back in completely. This needs done several times. Otherwise you will have a very heterogeneous cure. The fast cure Epoxy you're using just cannot be mixed thoroughly before it starts to cure. You want to mix for at least 5 minutes, but that epoxy (what you used) will start to cure if you mix it that long.

Hope you get to read this, as I think this info will have a huge impact on the results you're aiming for, and I'm very interested in this.

Honestly, the streaking you're seeing is a good sign that you're not adequately mixing the two parts of the epoxy.  The goal isn't to swirl the liquids around... it's to actually mix the two components.    Two paint sticks in a drill aren't a good "mixing" solution.  A paint mixer would do a much better job.  As for a few fun suggestions: , have you considered using an opaque or colored glass? How about a thicker epoxy? A slower-cure epoxy would also be much better at reducing the crazy-temperatures you're seeing... and with a much thicker viscosity, it's unlikely you would see unwanted/uneven movement in the shards.
Maybe the galaxy shatter result would be achievable with a "ballistic gel" style mix with gelatin, albeit you will suffer clarity loss in the success of the result.

9:40 If I properly remember what I was taught by a guy who works with epoxy a lot ... the curing of most epoxies is exothermic and accelerated by heat. This means two things: One, paradoxically, as you figured out yourself, a larger mold can cure in the same time or quicker than a smaller one thanks to all that heat energy. And two, wherever heat is trapped in the mold, the curing reaction is going to run faster than it does in the areas where heat has the opportunity to radiate. That second point is, I think, the main reason why the first mold cured unevenly the way it did.

Moving forward, I'd love to see a PRD destruction in completely-cured epoxy.

The “bubble” you were talking about is most likely a shear line. When resin heats up like that, it misbehaves in a number of ways. One of these ways is that it will develop interior cracks like the one you were seeing. Since there is still some gooey sticky resin in there with the hard/cracking resin, it stays together as if glued (I mean epoxy is just fancy glue after all) and you can see the shear lines in glorious 3D. Some deep pour epoxy would eliminate the overheating problem, but it would also take hours rather than minutes to set up. Upside: you could pick the viscosity you want, it would be clearer and without defects from heat like cracks, and the fluid would be more homogeneous.

A couple years ago, I cast a Hercules Beetle in resin. I had a different difficulty, but my solution could potentially help you out. Unlike the glass from your Prince Rupert drops, insects float instead of sink. I didn't want the beetle to float to the top, I wanted it suspended in the middle. Instead of casting all of my resin at once and trying to put something on the beetle to keep it in place, I eventually came up with the solution of layering the resin. I made three layers. I poured the first layer, let it gel (but not harden), positioned the beetle, poured the second layer, let it gel (but not harden) and finally poured the third layer. This surrounded the beetle completely, so no legs or other body parts were exposed.

This could be used with your Prince Rupert drop in resin. You could make the first layer and let it gel, then put in your glass, get it right up to the time when it begins to gel, and then break your glass. It shouldn't sink to the bottom, and could give you the result you're looking for.

You can get shear propagating through the epoxy if the curing stresses start pulling the epoxy apart through differential curing. We call this “rifting” when it happens in our pours. It can pull dissolved air from the epoxy either microscopically or microscopically. In either case we see it in the CT image and x-rays. This is very insightful for work, even though we don’t put PRD in our epoxy castings! 😀

Each brand of epoxy has their own set of guidelines that you must follow. How fast they cure, pot life, and most importantly, what the max volume of a pour you can do.
This is why you had problems with it being cloudy, because you clearly went over the max. When you do that, something that should take like 24 hours to cure, can cure in literal seconds and possibly burn anything flammable it touches.
Also very risky of you to actually be pushing the drop down while the epoxy is smoking hot. Just a tiny mistake and you'll slip your finger in and burn it badly. And epoxy is really difficult to get off your fingers so it'll burn for a while.
Love it when Destin gets excited about science in action!

Great video and I never knew about Prince Rupert's drops, what a fantastic piece of physics and chemistry. The exothermic reaction you saw is typically controlled by a mass to volume ratio and it's almost impossible to get a handle on the viscosity of an container of resin while it is going through an run away exothermic reaction. I've seen some very violent exothermic reactions with epoxy that is used in the aerospace industry. When you reduced the container size you appeared to reduce the exothermic reaction and the viscosity of the resin stayed a bit more uniform and in turn more predictable. There appeared to be an air bubble that formed at the bottom of the last experiment, that was very interesting. I am a retired tech services/chemist from the aerospace industry, my area was fiber reinforced epoxies. Carbon fiber, fiberglass, Kevlar, and some other strange fibers that were impregnated with all sorts of resins.

The resin is developing thermal layers, complicating the effect you’re after.  Try laying the mixed epoxy out into a one inch thick layer until it is near time to congeal, then pour it into the container and fire the drop. Thermal layering will be minimized.  No smoking either.  Smoke means it’s too hot, which will change the lattice of the cure, meaning it will not be a homogeneous mixture.  Plus, that kind of heat results in a runaway cure (too fast). Glycerin might be interesting, though it wouldn’t freeze the effect.  One could also try vinylester or polyester resin.  Reaction timing with those two can be controlled by varying the amount of hardener.  True epoxy resin might work too, but the expense, oh brother.  In any event, you guys should be more careful with those resins.  Some of the aromatic hydrocarbons soak right into your skin/lungs then on to the spleen and liver, never to leave. What I am seeing seems similar to a vaccume cannon. In a vaccume cannon, the container is sealed and then the contents are pulled out. Now the atmosphere is pushing in all directions, trying to fill that space. When you fracture the thin membrain in the back, air rushes in to fill the space and explodes ot the front. In this glass version, the shell is hard before the center is cooled. You now have less density inside that space. The mediem is not air this time though, its glass. A much higher viscosity, density and mass, so the movement is now at the atomic level, but with probably more force. When you fracture the back of this glass vaccume cannon, the glass is released to move forward as well, but it collides with the glass in front of it, braking it loose as well. The explosion you see at the end of a regular vaccume cannon still happened, but its one molicule of glass crashing in to the next one. That then happens millions of times in a chain reaction frrom one end of the glass to the other. IMHO

Wing bubble theory:
ok so tail snaps and internal stress is released, negative pressure chamber is now exposed to atmosphere and air pushes into void as fast as possible, air hits end of drop and has a gas hammer effect, shockwave propagates, drop may or may not shatter from gas hammer.

So here's the part that I think I might be right about: that epoxy is still drying, and chemical bonds are forming every instant, so any bods formed or shifted into a position of physical strain would hold that strain much like the prince rupert's drop itself; this saved strain is causing negative pressure in a residual air channel that can access the atmosphere and is slowly exorcised as air pushes in to relieve that strain. If you had globbed some epoxy over the drop hole immediately after shattering it, the epoxy would likely have frozen into a (very oddly shaped) prince rupert's congealed mass of its own, as it would not be able to physically relieve the strain before chemical bonds made it impossible to do.

You should reach out to Peter Brown. His YouTube's "about" page does have a P.O. BOX, email and twitter.
He does a LOT of work with various resins and would be able to help you find the right one to use. Furniture coating resins are intended to be used in thin layers where the heat isn't much of a factor. For thicker castings like paperweights, lathe turning stock and micarta, you likely want something completely different. I'm pretty sure I've seen him using one that is much thicker to start and would possibly allow the pieces to not fall tot he bottom right away.

I have two points that may help as well. One is that many resins are non-Newtonian fluids. However, unlike starch suspensions that get harder with force, they become thinner with force.
I also noticed that the cavitation of the PRD was causing the shards to squish back together, particularly the ones with vacuum pockets in them to start. It may work better to do try this in a pressure chamber and release the pressure before the resin has fully cured.

Ultimately, I would look into getting away from resin and go with a gel that thickens as it cools like a high concentration of agar or a clear ballistic gel. The results would be less permanent than a resin casting, but I feel it's more likely to get the result you were looking for.

An easier way.
Get two containers (like cups) and pour back and forth.
Repeat till mixed.
Use slower curing resin.
Or this:
Get a dowel, about 1/5 of your tongue depressor, and a rubber band.
Rubber band on the depressor at the end of the dowel.
Bam. Easy peasy mixer. I use one for mixing epoxy & and syrup (for my bees)

Have you considered replacing the epoxy with polyacrylamide?  That way you can alter the cross-linking ratio of the resulting matrix to change the size of the pores (which act as the resistance to the explosion and acts as the supporting structure), you can change the solvent (from water to glycerine, say) in the pores to change the viscosity of the material surrounding the drop to slow the movement down, and change the concentration of initiator or catalyst so that it doesn't set too fast (or overheat).  Polyacrylamide is clear but the downside is that it won't last like epoxy.
Add an LED light and you should be able to see the color spectrum and universe within.

the thing I noticed in the high speed is that the glass expands when it explodes; it expands with a far larger "coating" that likely is pushing back the entire time the drop is expanding (at a pressure that is almost assuredly proportional to the size of the expansion. If you were going to have a coating not explode, it would seem it would have to contain a good portion of that expansion that happens in a relatively "solid" block. If the epoxy is significantly elastic, it might be able to balloon out and then contract back, but if the coating is not thick enough to stay within it's elastic deformation, it will break; it is very much like a balloon that was blown up too much: pop!

A few suggestions that might get you better results and more clear castings:
1. When the resin looks streaky, it's not mixed well enough. Mix really good, scraping the sides and bottom, then pour into a new container and mix a little longer.
2. Use an epoxy with a higher max pour depth. It will take longer to set, but it will be more consistent and clear.
3. Measure when to put the Prince Rupert's Drop in by looking at the temp of the resin rather than how long you've been going. It will be a more accurate measurement. Just use a thermal gun.

Used to make ignition coils that are potted in epoxy under vacuum. You want to mix the epoxy inside the vacuum chamber to degass while mixing. Mix less vigorously so you are not introducing additional air. You can pre degass the two components in separate containers before mixing to get more degassing time. We used to warm the components during the pre degass to lower the viscosity. It flowed in around the magnet wire better. When doing QC testing it was amazing how the epoxy worked it's way in-between the 10K turns of 38 gauge wire of the secondary coil. The pour of the epoxy into the coil took place under vacuum also.

A tip for removing bubbles from epoxy with a vacuum chamber.

Fill up the excess space in the chamber with a brick or whatever else you have. Reduce the amount of air in the container as much as possible so it can draw the air out more quickly. It takes much longer to remove the air from a large empty box than a box that is essentially 80% filled up.

My mom has a workshop and does epoxy work and in her vacuum chamber we took some scrap wood and made some big solid boxes that take up space, so when she has a project we can throw in some layers and chunks to bring the resin molds most of the way to to the top of the box and then fill in the space around the mold too.
This way she can still utilize the whole large space when she needs to, but for small things she isn’t wasting a large chunk of her very short work time on air extraction. This way she can get the bubbles all gone, carefully add swirls or dye or whatever and then quickly vacuum again until it’s cured.

And fyi, the mixatronic is a poor mixer. It doesn't create a flowing motion needed for good mixing, just the twisting in that one area at a time. That's why vats and tanks that need mixing are looking for up-flows and eddies instead of one giant whirlpool. And epoxy doesn't like to solidify uniformly; iirc it slightly contracts as it solidifies, which is why your Day2:test1 was splitting along a stress-riser, sucking air into it.

A few suggestions:
1.a/ Curing time: It's been said elsewhere, but try using epoxy with a slower curing time/cooling the reaction. That will help with timing, proper initial mixing, and proper de-gassing.
1.b/ Polymer: Maybe something more like a true jel (short timescales) and less like a solid would work better. Clear PDMS might also be an option. For the shot itself (but not the desk decoration) a water-glycerol or dextran solution may also be worth trying. They're clear and quite visquous.
2/ De-gassing: definitely affix the drop to the container prior to de-gassing if you can (and vent slowly)
3/ Tank geometry: looks like the shape and size of the vessel matters a lot (acoustic reverb/shockwave reflexion)
4/ Tracers: embedding small particles with high optical contrast in the glass and/or epoxy would help motion tracking.

Just a quick note.. I did my conscription time in an EOD unit... containing an explosion in a liquid is a rather dangerous thing. In any case, that can cause very bad shrapnel depending on the force of the explosion, so take good care when doing these sorts of things if this gave you ideas for future projects. Even very small explosive shockwaves can become pretty big when contained like this.

the prd exploded in the resin that was still setting, i.e. still 'molten'. the explosion sent a shockwave throughout the resin. due to the high aspect-ratio shape of the box, the symmetrical shockwaves rebound and met in the middle. this makes a plane of stress and/or strain in the semi-solid resin sort of like a fault line in a tectonic plate. air inclusion occurs and propagates along this plane. the whole is divided into halves by the shock and the halves pull away from one another, due to cooling/setting/residual/just plain weird stresses, sucking air in through the shattered prd like a straw.

Using cheap epoxy from home depot is not the same quality as say total boat, ecopoxy, stonecoat, etc. Way too thick of a pour. Some epoxies can be poored thicker others very thin. Also would recommend using another container after you mix because unmixed part A/B can be on the sidewalls and that can leave soft spots in your work if poured in. You can use a fan to slow the cure process so that it doesnt overheat. When pouring into your mold place a popsicle stick at an angle and pour onto it. This helps release airbubbles. Would have turned out much better if he had mixed the epoxy properly.
Here are the instructions I found from that brand of epoxy resin

"FIRST MIX: Pour the carefully measured Hardener (Side B) into the container with measured Resin (Side A) and thoroughly mix for six minutes. Mix with a stir stick using vigorous, steady revolution. With proper mixing, some air bubbles occur naturally and can be removed after the pour (see Step 4). It is very important to scrape all sides and the bottom of the container with your stirring stick as you mix.

SECOND MIX: Pour the Resin and Hardener mixture from first mix into a clean mixing container and thoroughly mix for another six minutes.

It is EXTREMELY IMPORTANT to follow Step 1 and Step 2 as described above. DO NOT allow mixture to sit (or it will harden), overheat and become hot to the touch."

Three recommendations here:
- Try letting the resin fully harden, I'm curious if the shockwave is powerful enough to shatter the hardened resin.
- Try ballistics gel instead of resin. This should more fully capture the 3d visualization of the drop shattering.
- Try clear gelatin, as the ballistics gel may be slightly too hard to allow the glass shards to travel through it.

If it is smoking, you're doing it wrong.

Epoxy cures faster when warm. The key is to remove the heat as fast as it is produced. A cold water bath and a slower-curing epoxy. This will give you more time and and more consistent results.

And, of course, a higher surface-area to volume ratio, e.g. your smaller container.

But without the high temperatures, the epoxy will set more consistently.

Why can't you let the epoxy cure completely with the drop inside?

The first batch wasn't mixed nearly enough because you won't see any streaks if it is fully mixed, and the heat it creates from curing accelerates it's curing speed almost like a runaway reaction such as a nuclear reactor meltdown so it is very difficult to precisely calculate the exact time it will start to solidify but not be too solid to insert the glass drop into it. That "perfect hardness" stage is only about 3 seconds when starting with epoxy that is 70F. You can greatly slow the reaction by keeping it colder so if you did this when it was 40F outside (or do this in a walk-in refrigerator) you could increase the "perfect hardness" stage to maybe 30 seconds or even 60 seconds because you'd be reducing or eliminating the exessive heat it creates which makes it harden too fast above a certain temperature. Of course a much easier solution would be using slower-curing epoxy which creates far less immediate heat build up which would eliminate the problem of the runaway exothermic reaction, but I was just giving my two cents to help with the epoxy you had on hand.

One thing about the epoxy that crossed my mind if the ambient temperature there in Alabama. I had the issue of the epoxy in my garage floor coating curing too quickly because of the ambient temps and the epoxy component temperatures. Since I couldn't change the outdoor conditions I changed the only other variable I could-the material.
I looked up the cure rate/temperature chart and took a S.W.A.G. and cooled the epoxy parts before I mixed them. Worked great, longer pot life and a better cure overall because the as mixed temps stayed in control. I'm sure it's probably been mentioned in the comments, but you should NEVER use a mixer with epoxy. Hand stir only. You will get way less bubbles, and has to spend very little too zero time in vacuum, which is only going to speed up your exothermic reaction. Also, looks like you were using epoxy art resin, or tabletop resin, which is only meant to be 1/4" or less in thickness. Try using deep pour epoxy,  Great vid though! Love the look of it

The first batch wasn't mixed nearly enough because you won't see any streaks if it is fully mixed, and the heat it creates from curing accelerates it's curing speed almost like a runaway reaction such as a nuclear reactor meltdown so it is very difficult to precisely calculate the exact time it will start to solidify but not be too solid to insert the glass drop into it. That "perfect hardness" stage is only about 3 seconds when starting with epoxy that is 70F. You can greatly slow the reaction by keeping it colder so if you did this when it was 40F outside (or do this in a walk-in refrigerator) you could increase the "perfect hardness" stage to maybe 30 seconds or even 60 seconds because you'd be reducing or eliminating the exessive heat it creates which makes it harden too fast above a certain temperature. Of course a much easier solution would be using slower-curing epoxy which creates far less immediate heat build up which would eliminate the problem of the runaway exothermic reaction, but I was just giving my two cents to help with the epoxy you had on hand.

As someone who works with epoxy a little more regularly, I can say that

1) a different type of epoxy (something with a slower cure time) would work better, as it would allow you to suspend the drop better, remove all bubbles from the epoxy, and have a larger margin of error with regards to the timing of shattering the drop. Also, keeping in mind that different epoxy types will have a really hard time in a deep pour, due to the exothermic reaction forcing the epoxy to get too hot, and cure too quickly. So, selecting the correct epoxy for the job can make a world of difference.

2) the mixing method was sub-optimal for a uniform cure and the clearest result. If you’re going to mix by hand, you should use a normal paint stir stick, and mix thoroughly for a minimum of 1 minute while scraping the sides of the cup, then pouring into a second container before pouring into the final mold (without scraping the sides of the second container). This will promote uniformity in the mix and curing. Which will give you the clearest epoxy, and the most uniformed cure (which makes it easier to know when to break the drop)

3) if you’re going to mix with a drill, there are very inexpensive mixer attachments for your regular drill that will give a much better mix. However, using a drill to mix will always introduce more air than hand mixing, thus, will need more time in the vacuum chamber, or more passes with a torch.

Consider: superheated middle, hardens first, takes on net shape.
Surroundings harden more slowly, at net shape.
Middle cools, pulling in on the outside.
Middle is in tension, outside in compression.

Using silicon tools can prevent waste because cured epoxy resin doesn't stick. When cleaning be sure to keep the epoxy types separate. Wrap paper towels used to wipe one type in a plastic bag you can tie shut before throwing in the trash. Never wash tools used with both types in the same sink so it doesn't mix and stick to the drain or clog the plumbing.
Use a bowl to prevent encapsulation of unmixed epoxy in the crease, or corner, of a bucket or cup.
Shaking in a sealed container or stirring quickly with a wire whisk, a glass rod, or a solid blade such as a popsicle stick incorporates air bubbles into the mix. The cooking technique known as folding helps reduces incorporation of air, helping prevent the formation of bubbles. While steadily rotating a mixing bowl slowly scrape with a wide flexible silicon spatula from the rim towards the center. Without letting the spatula break the surface lift, fold, and spread the mixture to the edge. Repeat until fully incorporated.
Pot times increase at colder temperatures, resin cures faster in higher temps. The longer you have your mixture in a confined space, the hotter & faster the exothermic reaction occurs, accelerating hardening. The greater the surface area, the easier heat disperses. Mixing in a wide shallow bowl sitting in an ice bath should delay cure times, allowing you to work longer. Lower temperatures may make components more difficult to emulsify. Warming both components in a hot water bath before decanting, mixing in a double boiler, and working on a hot day all make mixing easier as well as decrease the time for the resin to cure.
To ensure preferred video perspectives use rigid scaffold to arrange Rupert's Drop inside your transparent container before you mix and pour the epoxy. With firm pressure you may experience some dampening of the vibration within the glass, but not so much that it prevents shattering.
The glass will most easily break at the thinnest spot of the tail. Rather than cutting or snipping use a fulcrum at the thinnest point of the tail. A long string tied to the tip of the trailing lever portion of the tail can be pulled to snap it. Avoid shattering glass compressed between your (¿ungloved?!) fingertips. Avoid accelerating shards of glass or molten resin entirely by standing far enough away behind a barrier.
The larger the containing vat you use the longer it will take for reflected pressure waves to compress the explosion, allowing the dispersion envelope to continue to expand.

My theory about the void that was forming is a little complex, but I feel it makes sense:

What you've opened under the resin is basically a vacuum chamber. You're on the right track with the idea that it's air flowing into the void, but there's a few considerations you didn't seem to factor in.

The 2 part was poorly mixed, leaving many streaks of differing refractiveness which you charactarised as "heat", but that'd only make sense if some parts of the mix were heating at different rates (which would also show poor mixing).

Another observation is that the top solidifies quicker, which you then push down, but leaving the top exposed still. You put the PRD in, snap the tail, and it remains in place, but the top is still partly liquid. The vacuum inside the PRD then sucks some resin in, which solidifies, creating a lid of sorts, meaning the vacuum chamber is once again sealed. However...

Remember the poor mixing and the streaks? Well, a vacuum is going to try and find the least resistant substance to suck in, and considering the streaks may essentially be a sandwich of the 2 part epoxy, where the "bread" part and the "filling" part touch will solidify, making an incredibly strong balloon, or "chamber". A chamber that is much stronger than the completely shattered chamber of the PRD. Thus, the two chambers equalise in their vacuum strengths, where the PRD is much more voluminous so seems to suck more, leaving those void "streaks".

In short, PRD sucked the unmixed fluids out of the 2 part mix, as a result of the PRD self-sealing itself with resin at the top.

I'd actually say that is a little more impressive than what you did, as not only did you create a snowflake, but you suspended that snowflake in transparent snowflake, then broke the snowflake into countless more snowflakes which are now suspended in snowflake, which additionally created more snowflake.

I think I can visualize the effect you were aiming for.... just using the wrong epoxy. The epoxy resin they use to make decorative wood/resin tables and stuff would probably work better. It's nowhere near as exothermic, and bonus - at a certain point of it setting and curing, its viscosity reaches a point similar to ballistics gel. In theory, that would allow the fragments to expand significantly, quite likely leaving "vapor trails" showing the expansion paths.

The other thing you could do with the epoxy resin is getting a slow hardening resin.
There are 12 hour and 24 hour curing resins, so maybe try grabbing a big pot of 24 hour.
Mix it the day before, but mix them at 1 hour intervals, so your sweet spot of perfect epoxy fluidity is a wider margin.
Then you also have a bunch of different viscosities to play with at 1 hour offsets, that way you can dial in the hardening window and get a replicable fluid to capture the drops in. Might help with the uneven hardening as well?
Anyway good luck with it boys, love you work!

My theory for the air in the epoxy is if you look at 15:17 of the video you will notice that there are two fairly large air bubbles from how the glass was made. When the Prince Rupert's drop is shattered the air is then free to move out of the Prince Rupert's drop. Which is why at 15:34 you see the starts of the air bubble at the top of the bulb. The epoxy is quickly hardening but the air cant quickly escape through the fragmented glass (other than what was pushed out by the original shockwave) and as the epoxy hardens top down the air slowly gets pushed out rather than bubbling to the surface thus giving you that wing shape in the epoxy. Love your videos, but you had too much learning curve w/ epoxy in this video… not enough results…. Epoxy is hard t get right…. But here is what to do for follow up video: 1) Slower clear pour resin made for this kind of thickness so you don’t get thermal runaway. 2). Stir by hand, scrape sides, transfer to new container, stir by hand again for a LONG time…. Then transfer to thing and suspend the drop 3) use PRESSURE to clarify…. Not vacuum. The pressure collapses the bubbles to nothing.

And of course, be patient. Let the things harden…. Why you were setting them off while still gelatinous? Unless I missed something.. that would be way more interesting…. Much love…

The acoustic wave from the shattering drop may be bouncing off the walls of the container and returning to the drop,  distorting its fragmentation pattern.  Underwater acoustic sources used by the oil-exploration company I worked for were filmed at 2K frames per second in a large, circular water tank.  The source was designed to release several hundred pounds of air pressure as quickly as possible. The bubble produced by the sudden release started out spherical but assumed a dumbbell form when hit by the acoustic wave bouncing off the wall of the tank.  The bubble oscillated a few times between ever-smaller sphere and dumbbell.  We assumed the spherical bubble would have expanded more if not subjected to the echo off the wall.

My college professor (Bob) warned students to keep epoxy temperature down by mixing on a cold day, with refrigerated slow-set mix, and no accelerator, which lets you mix for two full minutes, then pull out bubbles in a vacuum chamber.

One bright kid got that backwards, made a huge pour (two gallons?) with lots of accelerator, in quick-setting mix, on a hot day. Told Bob what he'd done. Bob's response?

"OH GOOD!"

(Bob loved safety demonstrations, being an ex-navy guy.)

First, it smoked.

Then, it burst into flames.

They tried a garden hose. It just burned hotter, and made clouds of steam.

Then they tried buckets of water. Still flaming.

So they emptied four fire extinguishers on it. It was now a column of flame.

Submerging the whole flaming mess in a water tub wouldn't even put out the fire. Stinking, highly toxic smoke. Nobody could go near it. This was back in the '60's, when the fumes could cause cancer.

Bob didn't say what grade the kid got. But I'll bet he learned something.

Hi Destin, fun science is great! Just a note on materials handling. Your insistence on using a mechanical stirrer may have spoiled the whole experiment. Those of us that mix resins every day know that hand mixing is virtually the only way to get a thorough blend of the resin and its catalyst. It is possible to see, in all your batches, visible viscosity gradients. The "swirly" bits represent incomplete mixture. Your mechanical mix has introduced air bubbles and does not mix resin coating the sides bottom and corners of the mixing container. When properly mixed by hand your pot of catalyzed resin will be clear and have very few air bubbles in suspension, it will gel more evenly. Improperly mixed the resin will have pockets of very hotly catalyzed resin that goes very exothermic surrounded by resin that has little or no catalyst that will polymerize only slowly or much later. Hence the splash when you broke the drops. Additionally, subjecting the incompletely mixed batches to vacuum may have released the styrene from suspension greatly accelerating polymerization in the hot portion of the resin. So, thoroughly and carefully mix till the batch is completely clear and you may not need to vacuum bubbles out and you will have resin that polymerizes evenly and completely. Cheers

The bigger the volume of resin the faster it kicks over and gels and starts to cure.   You can reduce the curing rate by refrigerating the resin and keeping it cool after mixing, or you can look into special formulations meant for larger volumes.    Also, the "smoke trail" effect in the resin means you did not get a very thorough mix: the bottom of the container as well as the walls need to be scraped and really thoroughly mixed.

@SmarterEveryDay From this video I'm getting the idea that you dove headlong into this "great project" without thinking your way in for too long.
I saw or heard somewhere in this post today that you have heaps more data than you have disclosed in the video so, consider my mental wanderings my own based on what I witnessed here today.
Given that every job, project or task has a logical starting point it actually begins at the other end when you first determine what the finished project should accomplish. You then work backwards towards the starting point by figuring out 1) what you know, 2) what you need to know & 3) what you need in order to begin. Once you've accomplished 1 thru 3 youll be ready for number 4 which is figuring out what you need to start the project.
What I know about Prince Rupert's drops (PRDs) prior to your 2 videos is basically nothing. However, from HS Art class plus 50 years of life experience since I might be able to help with the next batch. The first thing I see is that a glass blowers tool is not a very good way to achieve any consistency in making the PRDs. A ladle would allow for higher temps resulting in a thinner consistency for the pour resulting in more control over the drips/drops & more drops per pour. Before you go nuts making a bunch consider 3 more things, the quenching pot, the pouring height above the surface of the water, the depth of the water. You should probably be monitoring the water temp also. White hot molten glass can be poured like molten metal allowing for more consistent pours resulting in more consistent diameters and lenghts. (Mass)
Next is the quenching pot, consider using a fifty gallon steel drum. It should be placed as close to the furnace as is safe & practical as time and temp are critical elements. With a rocket scientist on the team monitoring the temp of the molten glass should be achievable. Next would be the distance from the ladle to the surface of the water. More specifically the time over distance. You want the molten droplet to have enough time to absorb some of those awfully long tails you were getting.
The last part of the PRD making equation is the depth of the water. You want the new PRDs to cool sufficiently before inertia meets the immovable bottom of the pot.
Hopefully something here will help you create enough PRDs of approximately the same mass, quality and shape that you can figure out the issues you were having with the epoxy because I have no real clues for you. 🤷🏻‍♂️

I've used that resing before. You have to follow the instructions when mixing it. You can't pour directly into the same cup and you have to hand mix it. It takes three cups. Pour cup A hardener into cup B resin and mix by hand for six minutes timed. Pour cup B into fresh cup C and mix for an additional six minutes or until it's about 90 degress F. It was not intended for deep molds. I poured it too deep my first time and wound up with an exothermic reaction too. It's all about how you work with epoxy. You can mix it up with a mixer like you have, but honestly, you'd be better off mixing it by hand for 2 minutes, scraping the edges before pouring it into a container. This ensures you get the right ratios of epoxy to hardener, especially since the hardener is thinner and tends to rise. And never pour them both in at the same timer. Hardener first, THEN the thicker epoxy. I can't explain the science of why, but working with epoxy, I just know that THIS method works the best.

If you do it right, you have about 30 minutes to play with epoxy before the viscosity is too hard to overcome.

I think the reason it blows up from the tail is because there's a small vacuum inside due to the way it freezes. The reason it's only triggered at the tail is because it doesn't take a lot of damage to reach the vacuum, due to the small radius of the tail. Once the air floods in, it follows through the whole thing. The sudden influx of air conpressed into the small tube-like vaccum causes the air to push the glass outward at a high velocity. It's not so sensitive at the bulb because there's a lot more glass in between the surface and the vacuum.

Half fill your container with epoxy ahead of time. Let it cure. Then rest your item on the already set epoxy and then fill with fresh epoxy. If you use a removable silicone mold you can even end up with gaps / ridges for fresh epoxy to fill in but still provide support for the drop.

If you make multiple batches of epoxy in sequence, with different start times for each one and blend them together, you should get a blend of viscosities.

Having some resin that is at that phase transition point and other resin that is less cured should give you a combination of support and still allow expansion.

You're making great strides dealing with the other challenges.

chemical reactions are temperature dependent and also sunlight (UV) can be a strong reaction catalyst.  there is usually more working time at cooler temperatures.  i would reduce the amount of sunlight as a variable, it could be causing the layering effect.  mixing epoxy takes far longer than people think. the viscosity prevents rapid mixing.  if you degas the individual components prior to mixing, could that get a more clear product? if you have a mixer with blades completely submerged and just a shaft at the surface, it may prevent so much air entraining (i have a paint mixer that has two washers welded to the shaft on a propeller angle). i would also try mixing and degassing at the lower end of the products reaction temperature range.  this is a great internal stress experiment.  do melted clear plastic rupert drops have similar characteristics (and why not?).   what about metal rupert drops?  are the shapes of the glass shards/dust interesting microscopically? i wonder if the are asteroidal rupert drops (would be spherical though) because they flew close to the sun.  does volcanic glass do this when it drops into the sea?

As someone who worked with epoxy resin, and did deeper pour for craft, deep pour, even with 12 hour curing type of resin, it often heats up, smokey, and make uneven harden areas, usually the top is harden first, then the inner area, and it makes unclear and smokey resin, which is bad for the projects i did (the resin supposed to be clear, and if i pour shallow, the cured resin was clear) after some research i found that there is some parameter that affects, the type and brand of the resin, the depth of the pour, and the environment temperature you work on. Some option that is used by other artist is to do the pour in several layer to minimise exothermic reaction

The reason the resin got so hot and wasn't as clear as expected is that it wasn't made for casting. Ideally you would want to use a casting resin, which is clearer, has a longer work time and can also be poured in thicker layers because it doesn't give off as much heat while curing. I haven't worked with casting resin before but I'd expect the time window in which the viscosity is how you want it to be is also way longer due to it's (in general) longer work time. The longer work time would also allow you to mix it thoroughly, which is probably another reason it didn't turn out as clear as expected.

So, I worked in composites manufacturing for a year, so I have some "professional" experience with at least one particular resin, and there are a few things i'd like to note.
1. Your drill mixed SUPER aggressively compared to how one could mix with a stir stick. This adds a lot of air and can cause problems when degassing. Also along those lines, visible streaks are a sign of insufficient mixing. We mixed our resins in i think 5 gallon buckets (maybe they were 2.5, idk) up to something like 6 Kg per bucket, and would mix for 5 minutes and degass for 12. Granted, we also had a much slower curing resin than you have here. It was also an infusion resin, meaning it had relatively low viscosity as to be able to be pulled into the part by vacuum.
2. When degassing, we would drop a scotch-brite pad into our resin buckets. If I recall correctly, our engineers had found the buckets bubbled over less this way.
3. "Super magic smoke time" is an issue of overheating due to resin curing being an exothermic reaction that is accelerated by heat. In any other context of resin use this is very much your enemy. Also the smoke is quite likely bad for your health. And as you discovered, the resin can easily get hot enough to burn you. To avoid this, use a slower curing resin/hardener, smaller containers, or add some other system to pull heat away from your resin faster.

The fogginess in the mixture comes from resin and hardener having different refractive indexes. The disappear if the mixture is mixed properly. When I worked on gliders (which are made from epoxy resins), I was told to mix until there are no streaks at all visible. If you're having trouble getting there because your resin is hardening too fast, there's two things you can do: a) select a different hardener, there's plenty between 5 minutes hardening time to several days or b) cool both resin and hardener down in a fridge. The stuff we had had a usable time of 3-4 hours, but if cooled down to 5°C it remained liquid for several days easily.

Hey I work with expoxy often and for certain the first bath had too much hardened, and every big jar you did the expoxy was clearly undermixed. Most important part is insuring a 1:1 ratio and thoroughly mixed, you will no longer see the squiggly lines through the epoxy when it’s properly mixed it will turn clear, if it comes out yellow or it’s Smoking then you’ve added too much hardened. One part is much thicker so you’ll need to either weigh the resin and mix into the thicker part or account for the thicker part not pouring out equally due to it sticking to the cup

As resin polymerizes, it shrinks quite a bit. And the faster it cures, the less time it has to accommodate those stresses, which is why you saw those air pockets forming.This is actually a huge problem in things like dental fillings because the shrinkage of the resins they use is powerful enough on its own to tear your tooth apart from the inside out. That's why most of the stuff a dentist uses is a paste consisting of resin and a high compressive strength filler like glass particles or ceramic powder.

Perhaps an epoxy resin was the wrong choice for this. A different type of resin would probably give you a longer working time as well as produce less heat while curing. The less heat it produces the longer the working time. There are several sources online for clear resins to use for embedding objects. I would suggest you select one of those and try this again to get a better end result. Having hot resin splash on you  isn't fun. (been there, done that) We chose a resin from "Brick In The Yard". But they're not the only game in town. They DO know their resins and the tech inside and out, though.

@SmarterEveryDay I can help with your epoxy problems. You need shade, and a wide mixing bowl to increase the surface area of your epoxy while mixing. Curing epoxy generates quite a bit of heat, as you discovered, and it cures faster the hotter is is. Positive feedback thing. You never, ever want 'magic smoke'. That means you have a runaway reaction happening. Your thinner mold worked better because  the epoxy didn't get hot as fast, or as much hotter in the middle than the outside. I know you need light for cameras, but you should do all the epoxy busines INCLUDING the waiting in the shade, then move to the light exactly when you take the shot.

Hello Dustin, I have some concerns about the lack safety measures taken while working with epoxy resin.
Epoxy is a highly toxic material and when working with it you should always wear a respirator with filters suitable for organic vapor preferably N95.
You should also consider full face protection either in form of a full face respirator or a face shield.
Additionally, gloves should be worn at all time when working with resin, and should be ready to be replaced immediately if exposed.
As someone who worked with resin before, seeing you spill and splatter epoxy resin around with minimal ppe makes me very concerned.

Be safe and good luck

I recommend a few changes.
1: deep pour epoxy
2: Build a scaffold to hold the PRD in place, then pour the epoxy. You can use a small blow torch to pop surface bubbles.
3: keep the epoxy as cool as possible for as long as possible. Maybe an ice pack wrap?
4: for your desk, use a table saw to free the epoxy, sand it up to 5k grit, then polish it. It’ll blow your mind!

The exothermic reaction, much like a fire, is self-accellerating. The hotter the epoxy, the faster it sets. The faster it sets, the hotter it gets..

You might do better to research the epoxies and see if you can find a siloconized formula that cures to a rubber consistency.

Sherwin-Williams Marine coatings guys might have more info for you... I know the formula for their SeaGuard 5000 line cures to a rubbery consistency in high enough volumes.

For the desk piece to prevent the vacuum wing of air - after breaking the drop - quickly plop something thin like plastic cling flim against the broken tail hole of the epoxy so it can't suck more air in - then cap with more epoxy. The whole thing will be stuck in a vacuum forever.
Excellent work!

Obligatory: Whenever vacuum degassing anything, only fill the container about 1/3 full to give the vacuum full room to work. use multiple cups if you have to.
Never ever scrape out the remnants from an epoxy mix cup - they will undoubtedly contain unmixed uni-constituents and those will remain sticky forever (think doing a resin countertop and it never cures on the surface). Best bet - mix, pour and scrape to a new container(s) 1/3 full, mix again, degas, single thin stream pour the final - should have no bubbles and shouldn't need degassing in the final container.

Using a drill or powered mixing method for quantities of resin this small rarely makes sense, and will actually lead to worse homogenization - you can utilise a wooden tongue depressor very efficiently by hand! It lets you scrape the walls and bottom, and swirl in a much more random pattern than just turning a mixing utensil in the cup :) By the time it's mixed fully it should have very few visible swirls left!

I've been using epoxy for 30+ years. And when one mixes up a batch like you did you definitely get an exothermic reaction. Since I'm using epoxy for woodworking and boat building once I mix it up I pour it into a plastic bowl so it can dissipate the heat faster because of more surface area.

If you are going to try this again I'd use a slower curing epoxy and one that is clearer. The other thing I'd do is put the plexi container into a bath of cold water to slow down the reaction. Sure, it will take longer to cure but you might get better results. Good luck. I enjoyed this. :)

The first batch wasn't mixed nearly enough because you won't see any streaks if it is fully mixed, and the heat it creates from curing accelerates it's curing speed almost like a runaway reaction such as a nuclear reactor meltdown so it is very difficult to precisely calculate the exact time it will start to solidify but not be too solid to insert the glass drop into it. That "perfect hardness" stage is only about 3 seconds when starting with epoxy that is 70F. You can greatly slow the reaction by keeping it colder so if you did this when it was 40F outside (or do this in a walk-in refrigerator) you could increase the "perfect hardness" stage to maybe 30 seconds or even 60 seconds because you'd be reducing or eliminating the exessive heat it creates which makes it harden too fast above a certain temperature. Of course a much easier solution would be using slower-curing epoxy which creates far less immediate heat build up which would eliminate the problem of the runaway exothermic reaction, but I was just giving my two cents to help with the epoxy you had on hand.

In my experience using slower curing epoxy might have yielded a more consistent curing across the volume of the container.
Fast curing epoxy has a stronger exothermic reaction than slower curing ones which makes an easier time for the inconsistencies to form (as the epoxy curing factor is also affected by it's surrounding temperature) and you'd have much better control over the viscosity of the epoxy at the moment of "detonation".

As I'm sure a thousand comments have already pointed out, you exo-thermed (which is undesireable). Two notes I'd make about epoxy in case they haven't been made yet: mixing it fast (with a drill) makes it exo-therm faster. When I mix epoxy, the cue that it is properly mixed is that no laminar streaks are visible in the epoxy: it should look entirely clear and homogeneous. A folding motion (similar to baking) against the sides of the pot with a popsicle stick is the best approach I've found. Last note is that when you don't exo-therm, the cure curve is very smooth: it will get into a firm completely solid state which you can still easily dent with your fingernail well before it has fully cured. That's the state at which I would explore snipping the tail.

You should try it again - Get a proper mixing tool, do a good vacuum, suspend the drop and leave it for 24 hours

-Only mix by hand (more agitation makes it cure faster, mechanical agitation adds bubbles)
-Important! Pour into a 2nd cup (at least twice as large as the volume of epoxy) and mix again. There will always be unmixed parts on the sides of the first cup.
-Degas aggressively until the bubbles subside (should look like much more than boiling and quickly fill the oversized cup then recede)
-There will still be some bubbles, but they'll mostly disappear when pressure returns
-Should be fully clear, not streaky (though I wonder if you're just filming in a way that reveals streaks that aren't normally visible)
-Keep it out of the sun and heat until you're ready to film. Heat speeds up the curing rate which generates more heat...
-(optional) Brush epoxy on the drop immediately before dipping to avoid bubbles on the surface
-Pour into your final container / mold

I think that bubble forming might be air flowing through the drop because at the end of the drop (i.e. the bulb) the glass has the most room to expand due to the air pressure, which then propagates backwards. The reason that it's at the bottom/sides of the bulb rather than above the bulb is due to gravity pulling the shards that are above the bulb downwards and thus towards one another, but at the bottom of the bulb and to the sides, this is not the case and thus air can force it's way out. I think that essentially creates a one-way valve due to the shape of the shards, where the air can flow out of the bulb by squeezing through small fractures and just barely pushing the shards apart but the resin can't flow back due to it's own viscosity combined with the aforementioned shard geometry. This are all just ideas off the top of my head. Really cool video, loved it.

Couple comments, not criticizing;

1. Total mass (A:B) increases exotherm exponentially.

2. Mixing speed is everything. Slower without lapping oxygen into the mix should fix the clarity and the “waves” you are seeing. That’s not localized curing, it’s just not mixed in those areas.

3. For reference, most aerospace grade adhesive cure profiles are 7days @ 77degF (full cure) though the working time and/or pot-life can be anywhere from 15min-60min.. it looks like you are going for clarity, and consistency. They commonly limit total mass to not exceed 100grams. (Ref: Bullet 1)

4. That resin may be making your experiment harder, kinda forcing you into being fast.

5. Hopefully this comes across as helpful and not critical. You are the best channel on YouTube. Thanks for the content!

Before watching:
It's easier for me to look at it like it's a drop of something like liquid soap on a plate, but stretched up from center. The enviroment lets it be stretched more than usual, so by the time it's cold, all the "stress" is in the "tail".

So epoxy that's fully cured becomes quite pliable when it's made hot. Perhaps going at it that way might get you a more consistent, less rushed result. Also it might be time to build a large vacuum chamber with gloves attached so you can manipulate things within the chamber. Put that vacuum pump in the closet and get a Penberthy valve and a garden hose. You can easily pull 20 in of vacuum with one and in half the time.

Other questions you might want to explore.
1. Does the "explosion" have a sonic "spectrogram" (quantized sound?)
2. Does the shock wave propagate at the speed of sound? Or what is the rate of propagation forward & reflected?
3. Is there an EM spectrum? (think sonoluminescent) What does it look like?
4. How does a light wave from the EMR propagate? I.e., What colors (frequencies) happen when or where? I.e., does the spectrum vary at a given point?
5. If your glass mixture is homogeneous, If so I would expect the fragments to also be homgeneous. I.e., do the fragments explode when scratched?
6. How big are the fragments?
7. Do the fragments have sharp edges? Corners?
8. Do the pieces undergo any chemical changes?
9. Can you shine a light through the pieces? (Spectrosocopy)
10. Can you separate the fragments via electrostatic charge (e.g., gel electrophoresis)
11. Mass spectrometer?
12. Does the drop form if you drop it in hot water? hot oil? or other hot liquid, freezing water? liquid nitrogen? Mercury? Liquid Cs? (I.e., how do you separate the heat from a chemical reaction with the glass & water?)
13. If you coat the drop with metal (vapor deposition) Does it still shatter?
14. What about a coating of rubber?

So there's a couple things you did wrong in regards to the epoxy.
You where using a thin coat epoxy that if poured too thick thermally runs away and can burn/melt plastic.
The large Crack and yellowing of the resin casts PRD was from that thermal run away just on a slightly smaller scale. If you get a thick pour resin you can do up to 3 inches of depth or deeper if the resin temp is really low.
Also another tip for keeping resin long term throw a little bit of dye in it so it doesn't yellow over time which all resin does eventually.
