You don’t want acrylic, you want ballistic gel. The issue is that the epoxy is either not set enough and it acts like water, or it is over set and you get little expansion and then spring back.

If you used something like ballistic jell it would allow the fragments to move, even when completely set. You could then adjust the amount of jello in the mix to change up its firmness.

A few thoughts: Why only try the one epoxy? Surely other gelatinous stuff would have given different results, possibly allowing you to capture the galaxy fracture pattern.
The "wing" effect in the epoxy could be a solidification surface, essentially the PRD caused a small area to solidify a certain way and it slowly propagated along heterogeneously mixed boundaries. It would be fascinating to cut that block open and see if the wing area has any different properties other than the optical.
Why did you find the way the shockwave propagated to be surprising? It makes intuitive sense to me that the motion was along PRD and out the tip, as the way it shatters is also along the tail and out the tip.
With the limited number of PRDs you had, why didn't you start with a stable repeatable setup like you moved to later? It just strikes me as intuitive to create a setup where you can more easily compare multiple attempts and different propagation patterns.

Please don't take this as me hating on it, I found the video interesting and I'm sure you have a lot of fascinating data that isn't in this video. It just seems like with a bit more thought about the setup and what you're doing that you could have gotten a lot more useful data.

I have a question, does the temperature of the water affect the strength of the drop? Would it make the drop any stronger or weaker if you used colder of warmer water? I ask because I would imagine that the extreme temperature difference is one of the reasons this thing can exist, and I also would imagine that it would get increasingly difficult, but more worthwhile to form drops in ice cold water because these would be the strongest? Im asking because this is how I imagine the outcome to be, I know nothing of these things but Im very interested in the science behind it all.

Not only the formation of the drop is important, but as well the formation of the epoxy resin. You can see how time critical these things could be, and I believe that there are a wide range of ways to create this effect, from strong drops and strong epoxy to weak drops and weak resin. As long as the goalposts stay in place, you could use the easiest way to experiment on this by using the most average forms of drops and epoxy resin. However, this would give an average return on the size of the end result, because I believe the strongest drops would have the most force upon exploding, as well at the weakest epoxy resin allowing the explosion to get out of hand or mess up the experiment.

So with all this in mind, a strong drop would be key, as well as a thicker soupy resin for capturing the best effect. This is of course all just hypothesis and theory. Perhaps as well a well lit and temperature controlled work environment would help make the capture go smooth along with a holding device for the drop and a trigger device to begin the experiment without worrying about shaky hands.

Tip: All plastics' polymerization processes are accelerated by heat and radiated energy, from infrared to visible to ultraviolet. Mixing such plastics in direct sunlight always produces uneven and uncontrollable results in the speed and distribution of the process (ask any old "plastic" boat builder). Most epoxies harden at temperatures that will not produce smoke unless accelerated by injecting heat energy into the process. A white sheet as a sun shade would still give good diffuse light for filming but blocks the IR and UV from effecting the hardening process.
Just an observation: Cavitation is caused by a sudden decrease in pressure of the surrounding fluid. What we see appears to be an explosion, but the cavitation says it's an implosion.

I believe you're using entirely the wrong material.

The material you're using is designed to be used in thin coats, not in large volumes. The out-of-control exothermic reaction, the weird streaking, and the inconsistent curing are all symptoms of the main problem - using the wrong material.

For as much as you do research on your projects it seems as if you didnt research how epoxy works. You are not thoroughly mixing parts a & b. The volume of your epoxy is way too deep. Epoxy is not meant to be poured so deep. It gets waaaay too hot you need to mix slowly for five minutes or untill there js no striations. Vac purging js not necessary. Also mix it in a wider shallower pan as to disperse the heat better which will give you a longer working time. Then after a few minutes you can add it into your deeper cube container👍
